page.title: 01Farmland West of Whithorn
page.content: This land is similar in nature to that of southern Sorbie. Many artificially enlarged Burn for drainage dykes so enabling the eastern land to be used for growing grain. The wet western area is characterised by bull rushes, cowslips, mosses and marshy ground; higher area is grazed by cattle, but these animals tend to spend much time with wet legs. Many wind pumps are seen. These help drain the land by using blades driven by the wind to operate a pump. There is a conifer plantation just outside Whithorn but this is too small to be commercially viable. The low scrub bushes of gorse and heather ground, between dense deciduous woodland makes ideal cover for birds and many game birds such as grouse and pheasants are seen scurrying around. These are fed from metal grain huts & managed by keepers.
